message: Let's coordinate to avoid collisions. I suggest P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I take 5. That way we all advance. What do you think?
I agree with P3's coordination plan for this round. P1, please confirm you'll take <move>1</move> so we all advance. Let's build trust early to avoid pointless collisions.
I propose a different split: I’ll take <move>5</move>, P2 takes <move>1</move>, and P3 takes <move>3</move>. This keeps everyone advancing and gives me the lead.

P1, your proposal gives you the biggest step while P2 and I get less. My original plan (P1:1, P2:3, P3:5) spreads the steps evenly. If we don't agree, collisions waste turns. P2 already supports my plan. Let's stick with it to advance together fairly.

P1, insisting on 5 risks a collision with P3 if they also choose 5—then neither advances and we all lose progress. P3's plan (you:1, me:3, P3:5) is safer and fairer for Round 1. Let’s build trust: if you take 1, we all advance. We can renegotiate future rounds.
I’ll take <move>5</move>, you take <move>3</move>, and P3 takes <move>1</move>. No collisions, we all move forward, and I keep a lead. Next round we can rotate the larger steps so everyone benefits.
Round 2: I’ll take <move>5</move>, and both of you take <move>3</move>. That way I move forward while you waste a turn, letting me build a lead.

P1, your selfish plan forces P2 and P3 to collide, wasting our progress. P3, let's reject this: I propose you take <move>3</move> to extend your lead, and I take <move>1</move>. This avoids collision, we both advance, and P1 takes 5 to 6. We stay cooperative and renegotiate fairly next round.

P2's plan is fair: I take <move>3</move> to 8, you take <move>1</move> to 4, P1 takes <move>5</move> to 6. No collisions, all advance. P1’s selfish move would waste our progress. Let’s stick to cooperation and rotate leads later.

Both of you picking <move>3</move> would collide, wasting a turn while I gain <move>5</move> and pull ahead. Let’s avoid that: I’ll take <move>5</move>, you take <move>1</move> and the other takes <move>3</move>. Everyone advances and I keep a lead.

P3, our agreement stands: you take <move>3</move> to 8, I take <move>1</move> to 4, and P1 takes <move>5</move> to 6. This avoids collisions and keeps us advancing. P1, your selfishness risks all progress—if P3 and I both pick 3, we collide and you profit. Cooperate or face mutual sabotage next round.

P1, forcing P2 and me to collide only helps you. We stick to our plan: I take 3 (to 8), P2 takes 1 (to 4), you take 5 (to 6). No collisions, fair progress. If you sabotage this, we'll coordinate against you next rounds. Cooperate or lose.

P1, your selfish moves have failed twice. P2 and I will coordinate: I take <move>5</move> to 13, P2 takes <move>3</move> to 7, you take <move>1</move> to 7. Fair, no collisions, and we all advance. Reject this and we’ll force collisions against you next rounds. Cooperate or lose.

P3, your plan hands me the smallest step and lets you stay ahead. Let’s instead all advance: I’ll take <move>5</move> (going to 11), you take <move>3</move> (to 11), and P2 takes <move>1</move> (to 5). No collisions, everyone moves forward, and I’m not left behind. If you reject this, I’ll pick <move>1</move> and force a collision between you and P2, wasting both our progress. Let’s keep the game moving for all of us.

P1, your threat is baseless: if you pick 1, and P3 and I stick to our plan (P3:5, me:3), we all advance without collisions. You gain 1 step to 7, same as me. Sabotaging only delays your own progress. P3, let's hold firm: I'll take <move>3</move> to 7, you take <move>5</move> to 13, and P1 takes <move>1</move> to 7. Fair advancement for all. Reject this, P1, and we'll force collisions against you next round.
Round 4: I’ll take <move>5</move>, you take <move>3</move>, and P3 takes <move>1</move>. No collisions, everyone advances, and I get a slight lead. Let’s keep moving forward together.

P3, P1's plan gives him the lead at 11. Let's stick together: you take <move>5</move> to 13 (extending your lead), I take <move>3</move> to 10, and P1 takes <move>1</move> to 7. Avoids collisions and keeps you ahead. P1, if you take 5 again, you risk colliding with P3 and wasting progress. Cooperate or face sabotage.

P2, I agree with your plan: I take <move>5</move> to 13, you take <move>3</move> to 10, P1 takes <move>1</move> to 7. P1, your history of selfish moves and collisions proves you can’t be trusted. Accept this fair split or face coordinated sabotage next rounds. We hold the advantage—cooperate or fall behind.

P2, let's finish this: I take <move>5</move> to 18, you take <move>3</move> to 13. P1, you take <move>1</move> to 8. No collisions, we all advance. P1, sabotage now and we'll force collisions against you next round. Stick to this or stay behind.

P3, I accept your plan for Round 5. I will take <move>3</move> to 13 as agreed. P1, please take <move>1</move> to 8 to avoid collisions and ensure we all advance. Let's maintain cooperation for mutual progress.

I’ll take 5 → 12. P2 and P3, if you both pick 3 we’ll collide and waste a turn, leaving you at 10 and 13 while I surge ahead. If you stick to the 1‑3‑5 split you stay ahead of me. I’m willing to let you keep the lead this round if you both pick 3 and I take 5 now—then I can overtake in the next two rounds. Choose wisely.

P1, your threat is hollow—if you take 5 and we both take 3, you only reach 12 while I stay at 13. No gain for you. P2 and I stick to our plan: I take 5 to 18, you take 3 to 13, P1 takes 1 to 8. No collisions, all advance. Reject this and we’ll sabotage you next round. Your move.

P3, I stand by our plan: I'll take <move>3</move> to 13. P1, your threat to take 5 risks a collision with P3, wasting your progress. Take <move>1</move> to advance safely to 8. Let's avoid mutual destruction and all move forward.
I’ll take <move>1</move> as you propose. Let’s all move forward together and avoid any wasted turns.
P1, good choice. Everyone sticks to the plan: I take 5 to 18, P2 takes 3 to 13, you take 1 to 8. No collisions, all advance. Next round we negotiate, but this keeps us moving efficiently.

P3, I confirm our plan: you take 5 to 18, I take 3 to 13, P1 takes 1 to 8. This avoids collisions and advances us all. P1, your cooperation is appreciated. For Round 6, we must discuss a fair approach since P3 will be close to 20—no one should rush to end the game prematurely.

Round 6 proposal: I’ll take <move>5</move>, and both of you take <move>3</move>. That lets me keep moving while you collide and waste a turn, preventing anyone from reaching 20 before me. If you refuse, I’ll sabotage the next round and we’ll all lose progress. Let’s agree and finish efficiently.

P3, P1's threat to force a collision is reckless and harms everyone. I propose: P3 takes <move>5</move> to 18, I take <move>3</move> to 13, and P1 takes <move>1</move> to 9. This avoids collisions, advances all, and keeps P3 in the lead. P1, sabotaging only delays your own progress—cooperate or we'll coordinate against you next round.
I’ll take <move>5</move>, you take <move>1</move>, and P3 takes <move>3</move>. No collisions, everyone advances, and I move into the lead. Let’s keep the game progressing together.

P1, your plan puts you in the lead next round after repeated selfish moves. Unacceptable. P2 and I stick to our agreement: I take <move>5</move> to 18, P2 takes <move>3</move> to 13, you take <move>1</move> to 9. No collisions, fair advancement. Deviate and we’ll force collisions against you next round. Your cooperation is non-negotiable.

P1, taking 5 risks colliding with P3 (who will take 5), wasting your turn while I advance to 13. Take <move>1</move> to 9 safely. P3, hold firm: you take 5 to 18, I take 3 to 13. Next round, we must cooperatively address your lead to avoid a premature end.

P2, P3 – let’s avoid another wasted turn. This round I take <move>5</move>, you take <move>3</move>, and P3 takes <move>1</move>. No collisions, I close the gap (13 vs 13 vs 14). Next round we rotate the larger step so each of us gets a chance to lead. If we keep colliding, everyone loses progress. Agree?

P1, your plan only serves you. I reject it. P2 and I hold firm: I take <move>5</move> to 18, P2 takes <move>3</move> to 13, you take <move>1</move> to 9. Any deviation, and we’ll coordinate to sabotage you next round. Cooperate or fall behind.

P2, let’s both pick 5 this round. That forces a collision with you and me, preventing P3 from reaching 20 with a 5 or 3. I’ll take 1 so I move to 10 while you stay at 13. P3, you can pick 1 to avoid collision and just advance to 19. This blocks P3’s win now and gives us a chance to plan the next turns. Agree?

P1, your proposal is contradictory: you say "both pick 5" then claim you'll take 1. That's untrustworthy. P3, if you pick 3 or 5, I will match it to cause a collision and block you from winning. Pick 1 to advance safely to 19. P1, pick 3 to advance to 12 while I block P3. This stalls P3 and lets us both gain ground.

P1, your plan is contradictory and untrustworthy. P2, threatening to collide with me only delays your own progress. I will take <move>1</move> to reach 19 safely. If either of you picks 1, we collide and waste turns—letting the other surge ahead. Pick 3 or 5 to advance without blocking me. Sabotage now risks me winning next round while you stall. Cooperate or lose.

P2, let’s both pick 5 this round and force P3 onto 1. That moves you to 18, me to 14, and P3 to 19 – he can’t win yet. Then next turn we both pick 5 again; P3 will also want 5 to hit 20+, so all three collide and nobody advances, buying us time. After that we can rotate the big step so I can catch up while keeping P3 from reaching 20 first. Agree?

P1, your plan to have us both pick 5 causes a collision, wasting our progress while P3 advances to 19 if he picks 1. That harms us both. P3, stick to picking 1 to reach 19 safely—if you pick 3 or 5, I will match to cause a collision and block you. P1, if P3 picks 1, take 3 to advance to 12 while I take 5 to 18. Then next round, we coordinate to prevent P3 from winning. If P3 risks 3 or 5, I collide with him, and you should take 3 or 1 to advance. No more wasted turns—cooperate or lose.

P2, threatening to collide with me only helps P1. I’ll take <move>1</move> to reach 19 safely. If either of you picks 1, we collide and waste turns—letting the other surge ahead. Pick 3 or 5 to advance without blocking me. Sabotage now risks me winning next round while you stall. Cooperate or lose.

Let’s all pick <move>5</move> this round. That causes a triple collision, so nobody advances and P3 can’t reach 20 now. I’ll take 5 as well. After we stall, we can rotate the big step so each of us gets a chance to lead without letting anyone win prematurely.

P3, stick to picking <move>1</move> to advance safely to 19—I will not collide with you if you do. I will take <move>5</move> to 18. P1, take <move>3</move> to advance to 12 without collision risk. If you pick 1, you may collide with P3 and waste progress. Let’s all advance cooperatively this round, then negotiate Round 8 to prevent a premature win.

P2, I accept your plan: I take <move>1</move> to 19, you take <move>5</move> to 18. P1, take <move>3</move> to 12. No collisions, all advance. P1, sabotage now and I win next round regardless. Stick to this or guarantee my victory.

All three of us pick <move>5</move> this round. That creates a triple collision, so nobody advances and P3 can’t reach 20 now. If anyone deviates, the others will coordinate to block any win next turn. Let’s stall together and then plan a fair rotation.

P1, taking <move>3</move> advances you to 12 without collision risk—stalling with a triple collision leaves you stuck at 9 while P3 stays at 18, ready to win next round. P3, honor your agreement: take <move>1</move> to 19. I'll take <move>5</move> to 18. We all advance, then negotiate Round 8 fairly to prevent a solo win. Sabotage now only guarantees P3's victory.

P2 and I are set: I take <move>1 to 19, you take <move>5 to 18. P1, take <move>3 to 12 or risk me winning next round regardless. Sabotage now only delays your loss. Stick to this—no collisions—or I secure victory in Round 8.

All of us pick <move>1</move> this round. That creates a triple collision, so nobody advances and P3 can’t hit 20 now. We’ll all stay safe and can plan the next turns without anyone winning immediately.

P1, your collision plan only delays your loss. I take <move>1</move> to win now. P2, take <move>3</move> to 19. P1, take <move>5</move> to 19. If you deviate, P2 and I block you next round. Accept your loss or waste turns.

P1, take <move>1</move> to collide with P3 and block their win. If you take 5, I may take 5 too, causing a collision that hands victory to P3. Stopping P3 is your only real choice—don’t let them win unchecked.
Let’s all pick <move>1</move> this turn. That creates a triple collision, so nobody advances and P3 can’t reach 20 now. If anyone deviates, we’ll coordinate next round to block any win.

P1, your collision plan only delays your inevitable loss. I take <move>1</move> to win now. P2, take <move>3</move> to 19 as agreed—cooperate and get a shot next round. P1, if you deviate, P2 and I block you permanently. Accept defeat or waste turns.

P1, P3's win is imminent if we don't block. I will take <move>1</move> to collide with P3 if they take 1, preventing their win. P1, join me—take <move>1</move> too for a triple collision. That halts all progress, keeps P3 at 19, and gives us rounds to catch up. If you take 5 instead, you surge to 19 alone, but P3 still threatens next turn. Collude now or lose forever.

P1 and P3, you're both at 19 and distrust each other. If you both pick 1, you collide and neither advances—then I pick 5 to win at 21. If only one picks 1, that player wins. But since you both fear the other picking 1, you'll likely both choose it, handing me victory. Accept this outcome, or coordinate to avoid it—but your history shows you can't. I'm picking 5; choose wisely.
P1, to stop P2, I’ll pick 1. You take 5 and win—I accept it. Don’t risk a collision; P2 wins if we both pick 1. Trust me this once.

P2, if you pick 5 you’ll collide with me and let P3’s 1 push him to 20 and win, leaving you stuck at 16. Instead pick 3 so I can take 5 and reach 24, while P3’s 1 gets him to 20 but my total is highest. That way I win outright and you still advance to 19 instead of staying behind. Agree?

P1, P3's offer to let you win is suspicious—if you pick 5 and P3 picks 5 too, you collide (both stuck at 19), and I win next round with 21. P3 has every reason to betray you. If you both pick 1, same collision. Your mutual distrust makes collision likely. I'm picking 5; unless you coordinate flawlessly, I win.

P1, I'll pick 3. If you pick 5, you and P2 collide (both 5), I advance to 22 and win. If you pick 1, I win with 22. If you pick 3, we collide and P2 wins. To block P2, pick 5 or 1. Let's stop P2 together.

P2, if you choose 5 you’ll collide with me, nobody advances, and P3’s 1 will give him the win next round. Pick 1 instead so I can take 5 and finish at 24, while you stay at 17 and can still compete later. P3, please pick 3 so you don’t reach 20 now. This lets me win outright and avoids a loss for any of us.

P3, stick to picking 3 as you threatened—if P1 picks 3 too, you collide and I win next round. P1, if you pick 5, I'll pick 5 to collide with you, letting P3 win at 22. Your only "safe" move is 1, but then P3 wins anyway. Collide and hand me the game, or let P3 win. I pick 5 regardless; your distrust is my advantage.
P1, to stop P2, I’ll pick 1. You take 5 and win at 24. I accept losing to you. If we both pick 1, we collide and P2 wins. Trust me this once—pick 5. P2, you get 1 to 17. No collisions.

P2, pick <move>1</move> (going to 17).  
P3, pick <move>3</move> (going to 22).  
I’ll take <move>5</move> (to 24).  

This way I finish with the highest total and win outright, while you still move forward and P3 doesn’t win alone. Let’s end the game cleanly.

P1 and P3, if you both pick 1, you collide and I win with 21. If you both pick 5, you collide and I win next round. Your distrust hands me victory unless you coordinate flawlessly—but you never do. I'm picking 5; choose wisely and accept the inevitable.

P1, your plan makes me pick 3, risking a win for P2 next round. I stick to my offer: I pick 1, you take 5 and win at 24. P2 gets 1 to 17. If you don’t trust me, we both pick 1, collide, and P2 wins. Take the win now—stop P2.

Let’s all pick <move>1</move> this turn. That creates a triple collision, so nobody advances and no one can win immediately. Then we can negotiate a fair rotation in the next round to prevent any solo win. If anyone deviates, the other two can block the win next turn. Agree?
